elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have aroused great interest as lithium-ion battery (LIB) electrode materials. In this work, we first report that a pristine three-dimensional tetrathiafulvalene derivatives (TTFs)-based zinc MOF, formulated [Zn2(py-TTF-py)2(BDC)2]·2DMF·H2O (1) (py-TTF-py = 2,6-bis­(4′-pyridyl)­tetrathiafulvalene and H2BDC = terephthalic acid), can work as a high-performance electrode material for rechargeable LIBs. The TTFs-Zn-MOF 1 electrode displayed a high discharge specific capacity of 1117.4 mA h g–1 at a current density of 200 mA g–1 after 150 cycles along with good reversibility. After undergoing elevated discharging/charging rates, the electrode showed superior lithium storage performance in the extreme case of 20 A g–1 and could finally recover the capability when the current rate was back to 200 mA g–1. Particularly, specific capacities of 884.2, 513.8, and 327.8 mA h g–1 were reached at high current densities of 5, 10, and 20 A g–1 after 180, 175, and 300 cycles along with good reversibility, respectively. Such an excellent performance is first reported for the LIB anode materials. TTFs-Zn-MOF 2, namely, [Zn2(py-TTF-py) (BDC)2]·DMF·2H2O (2), was prepared as a contrast to explore the relationship between the structures of the electrode materials and the electrochemical properties. Based on the structural analysis of 1 and 2 and ex situ X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, the TTF moiety and the twofold TTF pillar play a key role in the excellent electrochemical performance. The full cell of MOF 1 with NMC 622 delivered the capacity of 131.9 mA h g–1 at 100 mA g–1 with the Coulombic efficiency of 99.45% after 70 cycles and exhibited the tolerance to high-current operation.

elements.content: Electrochemical energy storage (EES) has drawn increasing interest in view of its extended applications. Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) occupy a major application space among the EES devices because of their high energy density, light mass, and environmental friendliness. However, the theoretical capacity of the traditional LIBs with graphite-based anodes is low (∼370 mA h g–1) and the rate capability is poor, which cannot satisfy the needs of new electronic devices. As a consequence, the development of high rate capability and high capacity anode materials is highly in demand to LIBs. New system architectures and electrode materials are constantly being explored aiming at improving the performance of LIBs.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Electrochemical energy storage (EES) has drawn increasing interest in view of its extended applications. Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) occupy a major application space among the EES devices because of their high energy density, light mass, and environmental friendliness. However, the theoretical capacity of the traditional LIBs with graphite-based anodes is low (~370 mA h g-1) and the rate capability is poor, which cannot satisfy the needs of new electronic devices. As a consequence, the development of high rate capability and high capacity anode materials is highly in demand to LIBs. New system architectures and electrode materials are constantly being explored aiming at improving the performance of LIBs.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are very attractive porous molecular materials fabricated by metal-containing units and organic linkers. MOFs have exhibited various applications in gas storage, separation, chemical sensing, catalysis, and so on. Recently, using MOFs as anode materials for LIBs has attracted growing research attention because of their flexibility and the pore structures which might be favorable to large lithium-ion accommodation space and suitable lithium-ion pathway. The reports in the latest five years on the application of pristine MOFs in LIBs are listed in Table S1 along with the references. The MOFs used as anode materials for LIBs are usually constructed by benzenecarboxylate ligands (e.g., 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate and 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate) in which the benzene ring and the carboxylate group provide the inserting sites of Li+ ions during the discharging process. The electron-donating character of the aromatic ring and the carboxylate group is supposed to be the principal impetus in storing lithium ions. However, the electron-donating ability of the phenyl or naphthyl ring is too weak to have a good performance in storing lithium ions.

elements.content: Tetrathiafulvalene (TTF) is a sulfur-rich conjugated organic molecule with 14 π electrons. Sulfur-rich organic compounds such as polythiophene and their derivatives have been applied as electrode materials into rechargeable batteries. In contrast, TTF and its derivatives have been scarcely used as electrode materials. TTF derivatives (TTFs) have more great electron-donating ability than the aromatic carbon rings. Because the solubility of TTFs becomes lower as the number of TTF units increases, in order to suppress the solubility in organic solvents in LIBs, pentakis-fused TTFs have been prepared and used as a positive electrode, but the cycle-life performance was still unsatisfactory (72% of the initial discharge capacity after 30 cycles). Considering that TTFs-based MOFs possess the advantages of organic–inorganic hybrids and have been extensively studied for novel multifunctional materials, while there is no report on the investigation as electrode materials for LIBs, in this work, a conjugated TTF derivative, 2,6-bis­(4′-pyridyl)­tetrathiafulvalene (py-TTF-py, ), was chosen to construct two transition-metal MOFs of [Zn2(py-TTF-py)2(BDC)2]·2DMF·H2O (1) and [Zn2(py-TTF-py) (BDC)2]·DMF·2H2O (2) (H2BDC = terephthalic acid) with the BDC as an auxiliary ligand to study the performance of TTFs-MOF-based anode electrodes for LIBs. The results showed that the TTFs-Zn-MOF 1 displayed a high discharge specific capacity of 1117.4 mA h g–1 at a current density of 0.2 C (1 C = 1000 mA g–1) after 150 cycles along with good reversibility. Even at a very high current density of 20 A g–1, we obtain a high specific capacity of 327.8 mA h g–1 with the average Coulombic efficiency of 99.19% after repetitive discharging/charging 300 cycles. The rate capability is also outstanding in the extreme case of 20 C and could finally recover their capabilities when the current rate was back to 0.2 C. MOF 2 presented the discharge capacity of 621.3 mA h g–1 at 0.2C after 70 cycles and the average Coulombic efficiency is about 100%. Single-crystal X-ray structural analysis of 1 and 2 and ex situ X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy were used to explore the discharge/charge mechanism. The excellent reversible capacity of this type of MOFs is attributed to the strong S–Li interaction of the conjugated sulphur-rich ligand. The twofold TTF pillar also plays a key role in the discharge/charge process. In addition, the performances of a full cell with the LiNi0.6Mn0.2Co0.2O2 (NMC 622) cathode and MOF 1 anode were also tested. The full cell delivered the capacity of 131.9 mA h g–1 at 100 mA g–1 with the Coulombic efficiency of 99.45% after 70 cycles and exhibited a good rate performance with a specific capacity of 45.1 mA h g–1 at a high charge rate of 4 A g–1. Based on our knowledge, full cells with MOF-based electrodes have been scarcely reported. It is a new MOF system for LIBs with pristine MOF materials.

elements.content: Compounds 1 and 2 were synthesized by the solvothermal reactions at 120 °C. SEM images of crystals of 1 and 2 are shown in Figure S1. The yields of the crystals reached more than 40% through optimizing the ratios of the reactants and the solvents. The yields are high in comparison with those of the other TTF-metal complexes, which allow us to explore the electrochemical energy storage properties directly using crystal samples. By adjusting the volume and proportion of the mixed solvents, compounds 1 and 2 were obtained with the same two metal centers Zn­(II) and two BDC ligands but with two py-TTF-py in 1 and one py-TTF-py in 2 (discussed below). The cocrystallized solvent molecules were determined using PLATON/SQUEEZE program, elemental analysis, and thermoanalytical measurements. The squeeze results are attached at the end of the cif files. Crystals of 1 and 2 are insoluble in common organic solvents. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of the microcrystal samples for 1 and 2 agree with those simulated from the data of single-crystal analysis, revealing their crystalline phase purity (Figure S2 in the Supporting Information). The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) curves of 1 and 2 (Figure S3) reveal that the first step lost all lattice water molecules (for 1, 1.48%, calcd 1.34%, and for 2, 3.86%, calcd 3.88%), and the second step lost the cocrystallized DMF molecules (for 1, 10.62%, calcd 10.91%, and for 2, 8.06%, calcd 7.88%). Then, the third weight loss happen at 316 °C for 1 and at 350 °C for 2 because of the decomposition of organic ligands, which means that the frameworks of 1 and 2 begin to damage at this stage. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area measurement for N2 adsorption is presented in Figure S4 indicating that the most pore sizes of 1 and 2 are in the range of 2–10 nm.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Characterization of 1 and 2 

Compounds 1 and 2 were synthesized by the solvothermal reactions at 120 °C. SEM images of crystals of 1 and 2 are shown in Figure S1. The yields of the crystals reached more than 40% through optimizing the ratios of the reactants and the solvents. The yields are high in comparison with those of the other TTF-metal complexes, which allow us to explore the electrochemical energy storage properties directly using crystal samples. By adjusting the volume and proportion of the mixed solvents, compounds 1 and 2 were obtained with the same two metal centers Zn(II) and two BDC ligands but with two py-TTF-py in 1 and one py-TTF-py in 2 (discussed below). The cocrystallized solvent molecules were determined using PLATON/SQUEEZE program, elemental analysis, and thermoanalytical measurements. The squeeze results are attached at the end of the cif files. Crystals of 1 and 2 are insoluble in common organic solvents. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of the microcrystal samples for 1 and 2 agree with those simulated from the data of single-crystal analysis, revealing their crystalline phase purity (Figure S2 in the Supporting Information). The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) curves of 1 and 2 (Figure S3) reveal that the first step lost all lattice water molecules (for 1, 1.48%, calcd 1.34%, and for 2, 3.86%, calcd 3.88%), and the second step lost the cocrystallized DMF molecules (for 1, 10.62%, calcd 10.91%, and for 2, 8.06%, calcd 7.88%). Then, the third weight loss happen at 316 °C for 1 and at 350 °C for 2 because of the decomposition of organic ligands, which means that the frameworks of 1 and 2 begin to damage at this stage. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area measurement for N2 adsorption is presented in Figure S4 indicating that the most pore sizes of 1 and 2 are in the range of 2-10 nm.

elements.content: Two-electrode CR2032 coin-cell LIBs using the as-synthesized crystals of 1 and 2 as the active material of the anode were fabricated and galvanostatic charge/discharge measurements were carried out. The voltage window of 0.01–3.0 V was selected as the operation condition. The electrochemical behaviors of 1 and 2 electrodes were first studied by cyclic voltammetry (CV) at a scan rate of 0.2 mV s–1 and the results for the first 3 cycles are illustrated in . For 1 electrode, a well-defined cathodic peak at about 0.75 V in the first cycle is observed and that is shifted to the positive direction (0.85 V) in the subsequent scans, which is associated with the formation of a solid–electrolyte interphase (SEI) film and might be related to some activation processes for the Li-ion insertion during the first cycle. A broad peak is located at 1.12 V in the first anodic scan. The peaks after the initial scans are almost overlapped, indicating the occurrence of similar reactions during the charge/discharge processes and the formation of a stable solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) layer. Electrode 2 exhibits an analogous redox behavior with 1.
elements.clean_text:
Electrochemical Performance

Two-electrode CR2032 coin-cell LIBs using the as-synthesized crystals of 1 and 2 as the active material of the anode were fabricated and galvanostatic charge/discharge measurements were carried out. The voltage window of 0.01-3.0 V was selected as the operation condition. The electrochemical behaviors of 1 and 2 electrodes were first studied by cyclic voltammetry (CV) at a scan rate of 0.2 mV s-1 and the results for the first 3 cycles are illustrated in . For 1 electrode, a well-defined cathodic peak at about 0.75 V in the first cycle is observed and that is shifted to the positive direction (0.85 V) in the subsequent scans, which is associated with the formation of a solid-electrolyte interphase (SEI) film and might be related to some activation processes for the Li-ion insertion during the first cycle. A broad peak is located at 1.12 V in the first anodic scan. The peaks after the initial scans are almost overlapped, indicating the occurrence of similar reactions during the charge/discharge processes and the formation of a stable solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) layer. Electrode 2 exhibits an analogous redox behavior with 1.

elements.content: The charge/discharge profiles of 1 anode for cycle numbers of 1, 2, 4, 40, and 150 at a current density of 0.2 C (1 C = 1000 mA g–1) are displayed in a. There is no plateau at around 2.5 V for the initial cycles, which is in accordance with the CV profiles. The plateau at around 2.5 V appears along with the cycling number. The first discharge and charge capacities of 1 were 1368.5 and 500.6 mA h g–1, which obtained an initial Coulombic efficiency (CE) of 36.6%. The low initial irreversible capacity is principally ascribed to the formation of a solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) layer and interfacial lithium storage. The conductive agent (Super P) is responsible for part of the irreversible capacity. The strong electrostatic interaction between the Li+ and the electron-rich conjugated TTF moiety formed during the first discharge also contribute to the irreversibly “captured” Li+. Therefore, less Li+ could be extracted out during initial charge. The discharge capacity of 1 decreased to 580.9 mA h g–1 in the second cycle and quickly increased from the third cycle. The capacity reached 909.2 mA h g–1 in the 40th cycle and then increased slowly to 1117.4 mA h g–1 in the 150th cycle. This increase is attributed to the capacitive behavior of the anode resulting in adsorption of a lot of ions when the electrolyte permeates into the bulk along with the cycling number. The capacitive and diffusive contribution can be calculated using equation 1 shown in the Supporting Information and the results (Figure S5) indicated that the charge storage is mainly capacitive. The porous materials are inclined to present this behavior. The initial discharge and charge capacities of 2 at a current density of 80 mA g–1 were 1469.4 and 480.5 mA h g–1, which obtained an initial Coulombic efficiency (CE) of 32.7%. The discharge capacity decreased to 620.1 mA h g–1 in the second cycle (b). Similar to MOF-1, the plateau at around 2.5 V does not appear for the initial cycles and gradually appears along with the cycling number.

elements.content: The cycling performances of 1 and 2 anodes were investigated at a current density of 0.2 C. As shown in c, 1 anode presents a good cycling stability with high reversible capacity. Even after 150 cycles, 1 electrode still maintained the discharge and charge capacities of 1117.4 and 1096.6 mA h g–1 and the Coulombic efficiency maintained 98.7%. It should be noted that such a high reversible capacity and stability have never been previously reported for the MOFs-based anode materials (Table S1). Furthermore, after the first initial cycles, the average Coulombic efficiency maintained 99.60% for cycles from the 5th to 150th, and the nearly 100% Coulombic efficiency indicates that the SEI film is stable and side reactions are minimal. The cycling performance of 2 shown in d is tested after the electrode activation at 0.05 C for the first 5 cycles and at 0.1 C for the second 5 cycles. After the former 10th cycle activation at low current density, the discharge capacity of 2 at 0.2 C is 453.4 mA h g–1 and reached 765.7 mA h g–1 in the 35th cycle. The discharge and charge capacities of 2 maintained 621.3 and 613.0 mA h g–1 after repetitive discharging/charging to 70 cycles and the average Coulombic efficiency is about 100% for cycles from the 5th to 70th, indicating a reversible capacity.

The cycling performance of 2 shown in d is tested after the electrode activation at 0.05 C for the first 5 cycles and at 0.1 C for the second 5 cycles. elements.content: The rate behaviors of 1 were measured at a constant discharge rate of 0.2 C and various charge rates from 0.2 to 20 C. From the result of the cycling performance of 1 discussed above, we can see that the capacity increased quickly at the former 40th cycles, therefore, in order to eliminate the increasing effect on the rate performance, the rate capability was measured after 90 cycles at 0.2 C had been completed, at this time, the increase in the capacity is not obvious. As shown in e, the average reversible capacities of 1 electrode at 0.2, 0.5, 1, 2, and 5 C were obtained as 987.2, 976.3, 940.3, 927.6, and 876.22 mA h g–1, respectively. At a high charge rate of 10 C (10 A g–1), 1 electrode exhibited a capacity of 824.8 mA h g–1. Even in the extreme case of charge rate of 20 C (20 A g–1), the electrode still presented a high capacity of 722.1 mA h g–1, which reveal its excellent promise as a high-rate anode material for LIBs. The electrode totally resumed its initial capacity as the charge rate was back to 0.2 C, showing its tolerance to high-current operation. Therefore, the cycling performances of 1 anode at high current rates of 5, 10, and 20 A g–1 were carried out (). The electrode was activated at 0.2 C for the first 3 cycles. The discharge capacity was rising slowly from about 300 to 884.2 mA h g–1 after repetitive discharging/charging 180 cycles at 5 A g–1 with the average Coulombic efficiency of 95.97%. Similar increasing trends were observed at 10 and 20 A g–1. The discharge capacity at 10 A g–1 was about 260 mA h g–1 at first and reached 513.8 mA h g–1 in the 175th cycles with the average Coulombic efficiency of 96.02%. At the highest current rate of 20 A g–1, the discharge capacity was about 200 mA h g–1 at first and reached 327.8 mA h g–1 in the 300th cycles with the average Coulombic efficiency of 99.19%. Such an excellent performance is first reported for the LIB anode materials. Based on the comparison of performances of various MOFs used as Li ion battery anodes (Table S1), it can be stated that the 1 is a high-performance anode material in the field of MOF-based anode materials.

elements.content:
Comparing with the performance of 2, the Li-ion storage property of 1 is significantly superior. In order to explore the charge/discharge mechanism, the crystal structures of 1 and 2 were refined.

MOF Structures of <bold>1</bold> and <bold>2</bold> and Charge/Discharge Mechanism

Compounds 1 and 2 possess a 3D + 3D → 3D twofold interpenetrating framework. The coordination environment of Zn­(II) is presented in Figure S6a for 1 and Figure S6b for 2. Two Zn­(II) ions are bridged by carboxylate groups to form a dinuclear unit. The formula is [Zn2(py-TTF-py)2(BDC)2]·2DMF·H2O for 1 and [Zn2(py-TTF-py) (BDC)2]·DMF·2H2O for 2. The dinuclear units link each other by a BDC linker to generate a two-dimensional (2D) square network located at the ac plane for 1 (Figure S6c) and at the ab plane for 2 (Figure S6d). Adjacent 2D networks are pillared by py-TTF-py linkers to extend a 3D framework shown in a for 1 and b for 2. The twofold redox-active py-TTF-py pillars are the notable feature in 1 (Figure S7a) in comparison with the single py-TTF-py pillar in 2 (Figure S7b). In 1, the average distance between the two-fold TTF plane is 3.67 Å, indicating that π···π interaction exists. Because of the spacious nature of the single 3D network in 1 and 2, mutual interpenetration of the other independent equivalent network fills the potential voids, producing a two-fold interpenetrating architecture (c for 1 and d for 2). The structures viewed along different axes and the different types of pores are presented in Figure S8 for 1 and Figure S9 for 2. No short contact exists between the twofold interpenetrating 3D net, which provides a free pathway of lithium ions.

elements.content: The superior performance of MOF 1 to that of MOF 2 can be rationalized on the basis of their compositions and structures. First, MOF 1 ([Zn2(py-TTF-py)2(BDC)2]) has one more py-TTF-py molecule in comparison with MOF 2 ([Zn2(py-TTF-py) (BDC)2]), which can provide more active sites. Second, twofold py-TTF-py pillars link the metal centers in 1 while a single py-TTF-py pillar exists in 2, which generates a much steady framework of 1. The steady framework could buffer the volume change in the MOF during the charge–discharge circles and prevent the particles from separating from the electrode. Third, there are π···π interactions between the twofold TTF planes in 1 that also play a role in stabilizing the MOF structure. The charge transport between the TTF dimers can be through charge hopping within the MOF framework, which can offer continuous electron conduction pathways in all directions, and in the meantime, promote the transport of Li ions. Therefore, the conductivity of MOF 1 should be higher than that of MOF 2. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) analysis is used to exhibit the enhanced conductivity and ion/electron transport. Nyquist plots of the MOF 1 and MOF 2 electrodes are displayed in a and the corresponding equivalent circuit is provided in b. Both of the two plots in a contain an inclined straight line in the low-frequency region and a semicircle in the high-frequency region. Generally, the diameter of the high-frequency semicircle is relevant to the charge-transfer impedance. By fitting the curves (b), the R CT values of MOF 1 and MOF 2 are 107.1 and 162.4 Ω, respectively. This result testifies that MOF 1 is an excellent conductor in comparison with MOF 2, which can be beneficial to the electronic conductivity and facilitate electron transport and obtain good rate performance.

elements.content: To further explore how the TTF moiety participates in the Li storage, ex situ X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements of the anodes for the fully discharged state (0.01 V) and charged state (3.0 V) after 10 cycles as well as the pristine crystals were conducted. For MOF 1 electrode, the XPS spectrum of S 2p for the pristine crystals is shown in a. The peaks of S 2p1/2 at 165.1 eV and S 2p3/2 at 163.9 and 161.9 eV correspond to the existence of S2–. Two peaks at 164.5 and 162.6 eV for the fully discharged state (b) and 164.3 and 162.8 eV for the fully charged state (c) indicate the presence of S2– state during the discharge/charge process. The new strong peak at 168.9 eV for the discharged state and charged state originates from positively charged sulfur species. Because the discharge/charge process is in the range of 0.01–3 V vs Li+/Li that is below the oxidation potential of the TTF moiety (3.7 V vs Li+/Li) and the cell is tightly sealed under inert condition, the TTF should not be oxidized. Considering that the electron cloud density of the S atom is high, the positive lithium ions could be accumulated around the S atom. Therefore, the new peak could be attributed to the electron-withdrawing effect of the lithium ions on the S atoms. For the fully charged state, some Li+ ions are reduced to metal Li and the intensity of the new peak is subsequently decreased, which is verified by the fact that the intensity of the new peak for the fully charged state (c) is weaker than that for the fully discharged state (b). The result illustrates that the sulfur atoms of the TTF moiety are the active centers for LIBs. The C 1s spectrum for the pristine crystals is shown in d. The peak at 285.8 eV is correlated with the C–S bond and it appears at 286.4 eV for the fully discharged state (e) and the charged state (f), which indicates the existence of the C–S bond during the discharge/charge process. The peak at ∼290.4 eV is ascribed to the chemical bond of −C–F which comes from the binder of poly­(vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF). Thus, the TTF moiety involved in the lithium storage mechanism can be expressed as .

elements.content: The Zn 2p XPS spectrum for the pristine crystals shown in Figure S10a exhibits two main peaks of Zn 2p1/2 and Zn 2p3/2 at binding energies of 1044.9 and 1021.9 eV, respectively, and the difference of binding energy (ΔE = 23.0 eV) between the two peaks indicates the existence of Zn2+. Slightly higher binding energy positions of the peaks (1045.3 and 1022.3 eV) for the fully discharged state and charged state (Figure S10b,c) in comparison with the pristine sample present the existence of Zn2+ during the discharge/charge process. Therefore, in our case, the valence of Zn2+ is not changed and the Zn2+ is not involved in the redox reaction occurring in LIBs, which is favorable for keeping the stability of the MOF structure. The XPS spectra of electrode 2 (Figure S11) show similar results to those of electrode 1. For the ligand BDC, Armand et al. have indicated that conjugated dicarboxylates can perform as redox centers because of the coordination of Li with COO–. Therefore, for the electrodes of 1 and 2, it is possible that redox participation of the ligands BDC and py-TTF-py plays a role in Li insertion/extraction. Based on the crystal structural analysis, the strong S–Li interaction and the twofold py-TTF-py are responsible for the extremely outstanding Li-ion storage properties of MOF 1 in comparison with those of MOF 2.

elements.content: The full cell was assembled using MOF 1 as an anode and NMC 622 as a cathode. The charge/discharge curves at a current density of 40 mA g–1 are presented in a. The Coulombic efficiency at the first cycle is about 65.20%, which increases to 95.65% at the ninth cycle. The cycling performance of the full cell at 40 mA g–1 for the initial ten cycles and at 100 mA g–1 for the next cycles is depicted in b. The discharge specific capacity is 169.9 mA h g–1 at the tenth cycle at 40 mA g–1 and 131.9 mA h g–1 at 100 mA g–1 with the Coulombic efficiency of 99.45% after 70 cycles. The charge/discharge curves at different rates are presented in c and the rate performance is given in d. The electrode exhibited a capacity of 45.1 mA h g–1 at a high charge rate of 20 C (1 C = 200 mA g–1). The electrode totally recovered its initial capacity as the charge rate was back to 0.2 C, indicating the tolerance to high-current operation.

elements.content: In summary, two TTFs-based Zn­(II) MOFs with the auxiliary ligand BDC were crystallographically characterized and first investigated as anode materials for rechargeable LIBs. MOF 1 exhibits an excellent reversible capacity of 1117.4 mA h g–1 at 200 mA g–1 after 150 cycles and outstanding rate performance. Remarkably, specific capacities of 884.2, 513.8, and 327.8 mA h g–1 are reached at high current densities of 5, 10, and 20 A g–1 after 180, 175, and 300 cycles along with good reversibility, respectively. MOF 2 presents the discharge capacity of 621.3 mA h g–1 after 70 cycles and the average Coulombic efficiency is about 100%. In comparison with MOF 2, MOF 1 with the twofold py-TTF-py pillar dramatically improves the electrochemical performances. Based on the structural analysis of 1 and 2 and ex situ XPS, the TTF moiety and the twofold TTF pillar play a key role in the high electrochemical performance. The capacity of the full cell of MOF 1 with NMC 622 reaches 131.9 mA h g–1 at 100 mA g–1 with the Coulombic efficiency of 99.45% after 70 cycles and presents the tolerance to high-current operation. These results indicate that TTFs-Zn-MOF 1 is a promising candidate as an excellent performance anode material for rechargeable batteries.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, two TTFs-based Zn(II) MOFs with the auxiliary ligand BDC were crystallographically characterized and first investigated as anode materials for rechargeable LIBs. MOF 1 exhibits an excellent reversible capacity of 1117.4 mA h g-1 at 200 mA g-1 after 150 cycles and outstanding rate performance. Remarkably, specific capacities of 884.2, 513.8, and 327.8 mA h g-1 are reached at high current densities of 5, 10, and 20 A g-1 after 180, 175, and 300 cycles along with good reversibility, respectively. MOF 2 presents the discharge capacity of 621.3 mA h g-1 after 70 cycles and the average Coulombic efficiency is about 100%. In comparison with MOF 2, MOF 1 with the twofold py-TTF-py pillar dramatically improves the electrochemical performances. Based on the structural analysis of 1 and 2 and ex situ XPS, the TTF moiety and the twofold TTF pillar play a key role in the high electrochemical performance. The capacity of the full cell of MOF 1 with NMC 622 reaches 131.9 mA h g-1 at 100 mA g-1 with the Coulombic efficiency of 99.45% after 70 cycles and presents the tolerance to high-current operation. These results indicate that TTFs-Zn-MOF 1 is a promising candidate as an excellent performance anode material for rechargeable batteries.

[Zn2(py-TTF-py)2(BDC)2]·2DMF·H2O (1). Compound 1 was prepared using the previously reported method. Analytically pure reactants Zn­(ClO4)2·6H2O (0.01 mmol, 3.8 mg), py-TTF-py (0.01 mmol, 3.6 mg), and H2BDC (0.02 mmol, 1.7 mg) and 0.8 mL of mixed solvent of CH3CN–DMF (1:1 in volume) were used and heated for 2 days. The yield of the red lamellar crystals of 1 is 60.2% (4.0 mg) based on py-TTF-py. Anal. Calcd for C54H44N6O11S8Zn2 (MW 1340.30): C, 48.39; H, 3.31; N, 6.27%. Found: C, 48.21; H, 3.26; N, 6.23%. [Zn2(py-TTF-py) (BDC)2]·DMF·2H2O (2). Compound 2 was prepared using a similar method to that of 1 except that 1.6 mL of mixed solvent of CH3CN–DMF (dimethylformamide) (5:3 in volume) was used and heated for 3 days. The yield of the black rod crystals of 2 is 44.0% (3.8 mg). Anal. Calcd for C35H29N3O11S4Zn2 (MW 926.7): C, 45.36; H, 3.15; N, 4.53%. Found: C, 45.57; H, 3.03; N, 4.59%. cln_elements.content:
Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have aroused great interest as lithium-ion battery (LIB) electrode materials. In this work, we first report that a pristine three-dimensional tetrathiafulvalene derivatives (TTFs)-based zinc MOF, formulated [Zn2(py-TTF-py)2(BDC)2]·2DMF·H2O (1) (py-TTF-py = 2,6-bis­(4′-pyridyl)­tetrathiafulvalene and H2BDC = terephthalic acid), can work as a high-performance electrode material for rechargeable LIBs. The TTFs-Zn-MOF 1 electrode displayed a high discharge specific capacity of 1117.4 mA h g–1 at a current density of 200 mA g–1 after 150 cycles along with good reversibility. After undergoing elevated discharging/charging rates, the electrode showed superior lithium storage performance in the extreme case of 20 A g–1 and could finally recover the capability when the current rate was back to 200 mA g–1. Particularly, specific capacities of 884.2, 513.8, and 327.8 mA h g–1 were reached at high current densities of 5, 10, and 20 A g–1 after 180, 175, and 300 cycles along with good reversibility, respectively. Such an excellent performance is first reported for the LIB anode materials. TTFs-Zn-MOF 2, namely, [Zn2(py-TTF-py) (BDC)2]·DMF·2H2O (2), was prepared as a contrast to explore the relationship between the structures of the electrode materials and the electrochemical properties. Based on the structural analysis of 1 and 2 and ex situ X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, the TTF moiety and the twofold TTF pillar play a key role in the excellent electrochemical performance. The full cell of MOF 1 with NMC 622 delivered the capacity of 131.9 mA h g–1 at 100 mA g–1 with the Coulombic efficiency of 99.45% after 70 cycles and exhibited the tolerance to high-current operation.

Tetrathiafulvalene (TTF) is a sulfur-rich conjugated organic molecule with 14 π electrons. Sulfur-rich organic compounds such as polythiophene and their derivatives have been applied as electrode materials into rechargeable batteries. In contrast, TTF and its derivatives have been scarcely used as electrode materials. TTF derivatives (TTFs) have more great electron-donating ability than the aromatic carbon rings. Because the solubility of TTFs becomes lower as the number of TTF units increases, in order to suppress the solubility in organic solvents in LIBs, pentakis-fused TTFs have been prepared and used as a positive electrode, but the cycle-life performance was still unsatisfactory (72% of the initial discharge capacity after 30 cycles). Considering that TTFs-based MOFs possess the advantages of organic–inorganic hybrids and have been extensively studied for novel multifunctional materials, while there is no report on the investigation as electrode materials for LIBs, in this work, a conjugated TTF derivative, 2,6-bis­(4′-pyridyl)­tetrathiafulvalene (py-TTF-py, ), was chosen to construct two transition-metal MOFs of [Zn2(py-TTF-py)2(BDC)2]·2DMF·H2O (1) and [Zn2(py-TTF-py) (BDC)2]·DMF·2H2O (2) (H2BDC = terephthalic acid) with the BDC as an auxiliary ligand to study the performance of TTFs-MOF-based anode electrodes for LIBs. The results showed that the TTFs-Zn-MOF 1 displayed a high discharge specific capacity of 1117.4 mA h g–1 at a current density of 0.2 C (1 C = 1000 mA g–1) after 150 cycles along with good reversibility. Even at a very high current density of 20 A g–1, we obtain a high specific capacity of 327.8 mA h g–1 with the average Coulombic efficiency of 99.19% after repetitive discharging/charging 300 cycles. The rate capability is also outstanding in the extreme case of 20 C and could finally recover their capabilities when the current rate was back to 0.2 C. MOF 2 presented the discharge capacity of 621.3 mA h g–1 at 0.2C after 70 cycles and the average Coulombic efficiency is about 100%. Single-crystal X-ray structural analysis of 1 and 2 and ex situ X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy were used to explore the discharge/charge mechanism. The excellent reversible capacity of this type of MOFs is attributed to the strong S–Li interaction of the conjugated sulphur-rich ligand. The twofold TTF pillar also plays a key role in the discharge/charge process. In addition, the performances of a full cell with the LiNi0.6Mn0.2Co0.2O2 (NMC 622) cathode and MOF 1 anode were also tested. The full cell delivered the capacity of 131.9 mA h g–1 at 100 mA g–1 with the Coulombic efficiency of 99.45% after 70 cycles and exhibited a good rate performance with a specific capacity of 45.1 mA h g–1 at a high charge rate of 4 A g–1. Based on our knowledge, full cells with MOF-based electrodes have been scarcely reported. It is a new MOF system for LIBs with pristine MOF materials.

Results and DiscussionSynthesis and Characterization of <bold>1</bold> and <bold>2</bold>

Compounds 1 and 2 were synthesized by the solvothermal reactions at 120 °C. SEM images of crystals of 1 and 2 are shown in Figure S1. The yields of the crystals reached more than 40% through optimizing the ratios of the reactants and the solvents. The yields are high in comparison with those of the other TTF-metal complexes, which allow us to explore the electrochemical energy storage properties directly using crystal samples. By adjusting the volume and proportion of the mixed solvents, compounds 1 and 2 were obtained with the same two metal centers Zn­(II) and two BDC ligands but with two py-TTF-py in 1 and one py-TTF-py in 2 (discussed below). The cocrystallized solvent molecules were determined using PLATON/SQUEEZE program, elemental analysis, and thermoanalytical measurements. The squeeze results are attached at the end of the cif files. Crystals of 1 and 2 are insoluble in common organic solvents. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of the microcrystal samples for 1 and 2 agree with those simulated from the data of single-crystal analysis, revealing their crystalline phase purity (Figure S2 in the Supporting Information). The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) curves of 1 and 2 (Figure S3) reveal that the first step lost all lattice water molecules (for 1, 1.48%, calcd 1.34%, and for 2, 3.86%, calcd 3.88%), and the second step lost the cocrystallized DMF molecules (for 1, 10.62%, calcd 10.91%, and for 2, 8.06%, calcd 7.88%). Then, the third weight loss happen at 316 °C for 1 and at 350 °C for 2 because of the decomposition of organic ligands, which means that the frameworks of 1 and 2 begin to damage at this stage. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area measurement for N2 adsorption is presented in Figure S4 indicating that the most pore sizes of 1 and 2 are in the range of 2–10 nm.

Electrochemical Performance

Two-electrode CR2032 coin-cell LIBs using the as-synthesized crystals of 1 and 2 as the active material of the anode were fabricated and galvanostatic charge/discharge measurements were carried out. The voltage window of 0.01–3.0 V was selected as the operation condition. The electrochemical behaviors of 1 and 2 electrodes were first studied by cyclic voltammetry (CV) at a scan rate of 0.2 mV s–1 and the results for the first 3 cycles are illustrated in . For 1 electrode, a well-defined cathodic peak at about 0.75 V in the first cycle is observed and that is shifted to the positive direction (0.85 V) in the subsequent scans, which is associated with the formation of a solid–electrolyte interphase (SEI) film and might be related to some activation processes for the Li-ion insertion during the first cycle. A broad peak is located at 1.12 V in the first anodic scan. The peaks after the initial scans are almost overlapped, indicating the occurrence of similar reactions during the charge/discharge processes and the formation of a stable solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) layer. Electrode 2 exhibits an analogous redox behavior with 1.

The charge/discharge profiles of 1 anode for cycle numbers of 1, 2, 4, 40, and 150 at a current density of 0.2 C (1 C = 1000 mA g–1) are displayed in a. There is no plateau at around 2.5 V for the initial cycles, which is in accordance with the CV profiles. The plateau at around 2.5 V appears along with the cycling number. The first discharge and charge capacities of 1 were 1368.5 and 500.6 mA h g–1, which obtained an initial Coulombic efficiency (CE) of 36.6%. The low initial irreversible capacity is principally ascribed to the formation of a solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) layer and interfacial lithium storage. The conductive agent (Super P) is responsible for part of the irreversible capacity. The strong electrostatic interaction between the Li+ and the electron-rich conjugated TTF moiety formed during the first discharge also contribute to the irreversibly “captured” Li+. Therefore, less Li+ could be extracted out during initial charge. The discharge capacity of 1 decreased to 580.9 mA h g–1 in the second cycle and quickly increased from the third cycle. The capacity reached 909.2 mA h g–1 in the 40th cycle and then increased slowly to 1117.4 mA h g–1 in the 150th cycle. This increase is attributed to the capacitive behavior of the anode resulting in adsorption of a lot of ions when the electrolyte permeates into the bulk along with the cycling number. The capacitive and diffusive contribution can be calculated using equation 1 shown in the Supporting Information and the results (Figure S5) indicated that the charge storage is mainly capacitive. The porous materials are inclined to present this behavior. The initial discharge and charge capacities of 2 at a current density of 80 mA g–1 were 1469.4 and 480.5 mA h g–1, which obtained an initial Coulombic efficiency (CE) of 32.7%. The discharge capacity decreased to 620.1 mA h g–1 in the second cycle (b). Similar to MOF-1, the plateau at around 2.5 V does not appear for the initial cycles and gradually appears along with the cycling number.

The cycling performances of 1 and 2 anodes were investigated at a current density of 0.2 C. As shown in c, 1 anode presents a good cycling stability with high reversible capacity. Even after 150 cycles, 1 electrode still maintained the discharge and charge capacities of 1117.4 and 1096.6 mA h g–1 and the Coulombic efficiency maintained 98.7%. It should be noted that such a high reversible capacity and stability have never been previously reported for the MOFs-based anode materials (Table S1). Furthermore, after the first initial cycles, the average Coulombic efficiency maintained 99.60% for cycles from the 5th to 150th, and the nearly 100% Coulombic efficiency indicates that the SEI film is stable and side reactions are minimal. The cycling performance of 2 shown in d is tested after the electrode activation at 0.05 C for the first 5 cycles and at 0.1 C for the second 5 cycles. After the former 10th cycle activation at low current density, the discharge capacity of 2 at 0.2 C is 453.4 mA h g–1 and reached 765.7 mA h g–1 in the 35th cycle. The discharge and charge capacities of 2 maintained 621.3 and 613.0 mA h g–1 after repetitive discharging/charging to 70 cycles and the average Coulombic efficiency is about 100% for cycles from the 5th to 70th, indicating a reversible capacity.

cln_elements.content:
The rate behaviors of 1 were measured at a constant discharge rate of 0.2 C and various charge rates from 0.2 to 20 C. From the result of the cycling performance of 1 discussed above, we can see that the capacity increased quickly at the former 40th cycles, therefore, in order to eliminate the increasing effect on the rate performance, the rate capability was measured after 90 cycles at 0.2 C had been completed, at this time, the increase in the capacity is not obvious. As shown in e, the average reversible capacities of 1 electrode at 0.2, 0.5, 1, 2, and 5 C were obtained as 987.2, 976.3, 940.3, 927.6, and 876.22 mA h g–1, respectively. At a high charge rate of 10 C (10 A g–1), 1 electrode exhibited a capacity of 824.8 mA h g–1. Even in the extreme case of charge rate of 20 C (20 A g–1), the electrode still presented a high capacity of 722.1 mA h g–1, which reveal its excellent promise as a high-rate anode material for LIBs. The electrode totally resumed its initial capacity as the charge rate was back to 0.2 C, showing its tolerance to high-current operation. Therefore, the cycling performances of 1 anode at high current rates of 5, 10, and 20 A g–1 were carried out (). The electrode was activated at 0.2 C for the first 3 cycles. The discharge capacity was rising slowly from about 300 to 884.2 mA h g–1 after repetitive discharging/charging 180 cycles at 5 A g–1 with the average Coulombic efficiency of 95.97%. Similar increasing trends were observed at 10 and 20 A g–1. The discharge capacity at 10 A g–1 was about 260 mA h g–1 at first and reached 513.8 mA h g–1 in the 175th cycles with the average Coulombic efficiency of 96.02%. At the highest current rate of 20 A g–1, the discharge capacity was about 200 mA h g–1 at first and reached 327.8 mA h g–1 in the 300th cycles with the average Coulombic efficiency of 99.19%. Such an excellent performance is first reported for the LIB anode materials. Based on the comparison of performances of various MOFs used as Li ion battery anodes (Table S1), it can be stated that the 1 is a high-performance anode material in the field of MOF-based anode materials.

The rate behaviors of 2 were examined at a constant discharge rate of 0.2 C and several charge rates from 0.05 to 20 C. The rate performance of 2 is shown in f. The reversible capacities of the 2 electrode at 0.05, 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1, 2, and 5 C were obtained as 436.2, 353.5, 336.2, 344.7, 356.4, 348.0, and 339.9 mA h g–1, respectively. With elevated current rates to 10 and 20 C, discharge capacities can be maintained at 339.4 and 314.3 mA h g–1. When the current rate was returned to 0.2 C, the electrode recovered their capacities as those at the initial stage, showing the stability of the anode material during the rate cycling process.

The superior performance of MOF 1 to that of MOF 2 can be rationalized on the basis of their compositions and structures. First, MOF 1 ([Zn2(py-TTF-py)2(BDC)2]) has one more py-TTF-py molecule in comparison with MOF 2 ([Zn2(py-TTF-py) (BDC)2]), which can provide more active sites. Second, twofold py-TTF-py pillars link the metal centers in 1 while a single py-TTF-py pillar exists in 2, which generates a much steady framework of 1. The steady framework could buffer the volume change in the MOF during the charge–discharge circles and prevent the particles from separating from the electrode. Third, there are π···π interactions between the twofold TTF planes in 1 that also play a role in stabilizing the MOF structure. The charge transport between the TTF dimers can be through charge hopping within the MOF framework, which can offer continuous electron conduction pathways in all directions, and in the meantime, promote the transport of Li ions. Therefore, the conductivity of MOF 1 should be higher than that of MOF 2. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) analysis is used to exhibit the enhanced conductivity and ion/electron transport. Nyquist plots of the MOF 1 and MOF 2 electrodes are displayed in a and the corresponding equivalent circuit is provided in b. Both of the two plots in a contain an inclined straight line in the low-frequency region and a semicircle in the high-frequency region. Generally, the diameter of the high-frequency semicircle is relevant to the charge-transfer impedance. By fitting the curves (b), the R CT values of MOF 1 and MOF 2 are 107.1 and 162.4 Ω, respectively. This result testifies that MOF 1 is an excellent conductor in comparison with MOF 2, which can be beneficial to the electronic conductivity and facilitate electron transport and obtain good rate performance.

Full Cell Performance

The full cell was assembled using MOF 1 as an anode and NMC 622 as a cathode. The charge/discharge curves at a current density of 40 mA g–1 are presented in a. The Coulombic efficiency at the first cycle is about 65.20%, which increases to 95.65% at the ninth cycle. The cycling performance of the full cell at 40 mA g–1 for the initial ten cycles and at 100 mA g–1 for the next cycles is depicted in b. The discharge specific capacity is 169.9 mA h g–1 at the tenth cycle at 40 mA g–1 and 131.9 mA h g–1 at 100 mA g–1 with the Coulombic efficiency of 99.45% after 70 cycles. The charge/discharge curves at different rates are presented in c and the rate performance is given in d. The electrode exhibited a capacity of 45.1 mA h g–1 at a high charge rate of 20 C (1 C = 200 mA g–1). The electrode totally recovered its initial capacity as the charge rate was back to 0.2 C, indicating the tolerance to high-current operation.

Conclusions

In summary, two TTFs-based Zn­(II) MOFs with the auxiliary ligand BDC were crystallographically characterized and first investigated as anode materials for rechargeable LIBs. MOF 1 exhibits an excellent reversible capacity of 1117.4 mA h g–1 at 200 mA g–1 after 150 cycles and outstanding rate performance. Remarkably, specific capacities of 884.2, 513.8, and 327.8 mA h g–1 are reached at high current densities of 5, 10, and 20 A g–1 after 180, 175, and 300 cycles along with good reversibility, respectively. MOF 2 presents the discharge capacity of 621.3 mA h g–1 after 70 cycles and the average Coulombic efficiency is about 100%. In comparison with MOF 2, MOF 1 with the twofold py-TTF-py pillar dramatically improves the electrochemical performances. Based on the structural analysis of 1 and 2 and ex situ XPS, the TTF moiety and the twofold TTF pillar play a key role in the high electrochemical performance. The capacity of the full cell of MOF 1 with NMC 622 reaches 131.9 mA h g–1 at 100 mA g–1 with the Coulombic efficiency of 99.45% after 70 cycles and presents the tolerance to high-current operation. These results indicate that TTFs-Zn-MOF 1 is a promising candidate as an excellent performance anode material for rechargeable batteries.

The rate behaviors of 1 were measured at a constant discharge rate of 0.2 C and various charge rates from 0.2 to 20 C. From the result of the cycling performance of 1 discussed above, we can see that the capacity increased quickly at the former 40th cycles, therefore, in order to eliminate the increasing effect on the rate performance, the rate capability was measured after 90 cycles at 0.2 C had been completed, at this time, the increase in the capacity is not obvious.
